what: Can I use TaxSEA with 16S rRNA gene sequencing data?
title: Frequently Asked Questions
text: Technically, yes works best shotgun metagenomic data. TaxSEA designed around species- strain-level resolution. 16S data ’re usually limited higher taxonomic ranks, means lose lot biological resolution, many meaningful traits (e.g. metabolite production) can’t assigned confidently. said, ’ve included genus-level taxon sets database, TaxSEA still run can useful high-level patterns. Just aware results coarser generally less powerful using shotgun metagenomics.

what: Why does TaxSEA use species-level data instead of strain-level?

text: deliberately work species level bring consistency heterogeneous human microbiome data. Strain-level profiles even variable across people species. practice, makes enrichment-style analyses noisy, slow, hard reproduce. make trade-: lose fine-grained detail, gain stability, speed, interpretability. ’s also practical reason. many traits TaxSEA uses, underlying evidence either conserved species level (e.g. oxygen tolerance, broad metabolic capacity, prior disease associations), comes experiments one type strains. even wanted work fully strain resolution, biological annotation often isn’t . Yes, means may miss strain-specific effects individual samples. population-scale human microbiome studies, species-level analysis strikes better balance biological meaning practical usability.

title: Single-sample enrichment with ssTaxSEA
text: Standard TaxSEA works group level. run differential abundance analysis, get fold change taxon, ask whether biologically related taxa shift together. ’s powerful characterising differs groups. sometimes interesting question individuals: patients IBD cohort show oral bacteria signature? person’s microbiome look “disease-like” “health-like” particular trait? Can stratify cohort enrichment patterns rather diagnosis alone? Group-level enrichment can’t answer questions collapses individuals single summary statistic. ssTaxSEA extends TaxSEA produce enrichment score every sample, every taxon set.

title: Single-sample enrichment with ssTaxSEA
text: core idea borrowed single-sample Gene Set Enrichment Analysis (ssGSEA), adapted microbiome count data. approach four steps: CLR transform. Raw counts transformed using centered log-ratio, accounts compositional nature microbiome data. Zeros replaced small pseudocount (0.5) transformation. Z-score taxon across cohort. CLR transformation, taxon z-scored across samples. critical step. means values longer reflect within-sample abundance, instead reflect much higher lower taxon given sample relative cohort mean. Without step, asking “taxa abundant person?” rather “person unusually high levels taxa compared everyone else?”. Rank score. sample, z-scores ranked ssGSEA-style weighted running-sum enrichment score computed taxon set. KS test. Kolmogorov-Smirnov p-value computed per sample per set, testing whether set members shifted relative taxa sample. output matrix enrichment scores (samples x taxon sets) corresponding matrix p-values.

title: Single-sample enrichment with ssTaxSEA
text: worth emphasising ’s key difference naive per-sample approach one actually works. Consider oral bacteria IBD cohort. group level, taxa consistently elevated IBD relative healthy controls, TaxSEA picks easily fold changes. individual sample, oral bacteria unlikely abundant taxa. might sit moderate abundance IBD samples low abundance controls. simply rank sample’s taxa abundance run enrichment, oral bacteria won’t stand either group groups dominant gut commensals. within-sample ranking buries -group signal. Z-scoring across cohort solves . taxon gets high z-score sample sample average. IBD samples, oral bacteria positive z-scores (elevated relative cohort), healthy samples, negative z-scores. enrichment test picks exactly pattern expect.

text: ssTaxSEA accepts TSE objects directly. extract count assay use rownames() taxon identifiers.
code: library(mia) library(TaxSEA)  data(GlobalPatterns, package = "mia") tse <- GlobalPatterns  # Subset to two sample types tse <- tse[, colData(tse)$SampleType %in% c("Feces", "Soil")] tse <- tse[rowSums(assay(tse, "counts") > 0) >= 2, ]  res <- ssTaxSEA(tse, min_set_size = 5) dim(res$scores)

Sample size. Z-scoring requires reasonable number samples estimate mean standard deviation taxon. samples (fewer ~10), estimates noisy. what: The challenge with interpreting differences in microbiome data
title: Why use taxon set enrichment analysis?
text: human microbiome studies, common goal compare microbial profiles groups. example, treated vs untreated, disease vs control, timepoint 1 vs timepoint 2. usually differential abundance (DA) analysis, tests whether individual bacteria differ groups. many DA methods, share basic premise: test microbes one one. Although standard practice, raises problem rarely discussed. People rarely share exact microbial species. Even large cohorts, taxa low-prevalence. example, Human Microbiome Project, applying modest 20% prevalence filter (species must appear ≥20% samples) removes vast majority species analysis.  Figure 1. left, heatmap species-level profiles eight randomly selected participants Human Microbiome Project shows samples cluster almost perfectly individual, highlighting strong inter-individual variation. right, histogram common commensal species prevalence demonstrates many taxa absent samples, illustrating species-level differential abundance often sparse hard reproduce. time, still consensus “best” DA method. fact, method choice can dominate biology: across 53 real gut microbiome studies, several widely used DA tools produced inconsistent results. benchmark suggests much call DA signal often prevalence-driven (zeros vs non-zeros) rather subtle abundance shifts Pelto et al., 2025 Much field therefore focused finding optimal DA method. fundamental question rarely ask: differential abundance right question begin ? course, possible single microbe drives phenotype. one bacterium responsible complex diseases inflammatory bowel disease, likely identified long ago. Instead, observe overwhelming majority human microbiome studies dominance single species, coordinated shifts across whole communities, patterns often described terms diversity dysbiosis. problem concepts usually actionable. relative descriptions: single “dysbiotic” “healthy” microbiome, even diversity contextual measure rather biological mechanism O’Toole et al., 2023. Recent large-scale meta-analyses reinforce view, showing many -called dysbiotic signatures reflect shared, non-specific response disease limited diagnostic mechanistic value Duvallet et al., 2017. ’omics fields, single-feature testing makes far sense. comparing gene expression, epigenomes, proteomes, samples broadly share set features, differ levels, whether features exist . microbiome data, assumption breaks completely: universally shared species. short: traditional differential abundance asks us compare microbes one one, human microbiomes don’t work way. species rare, poorly shared people, results depend heavily method choose. usually observe real studies single “causal” microbes, broad, coordinated shifts across communities: patterns DA struggles capture consistent biologically meaningful way.

what: The idea behind Taxon Set Enrichment Analysis
title: Why use taxon set enrichment analysis?
text: Taxon Set Enrichment Analysis starts simple observation: human microbiome studies, biology rarely driven single species. changes instead groups microbes share common trait. Rather asking “individual bugs changed?”, TSEA asks useful question: “microbes shared biological property shifting together?” example, seeing shifts : facultative anaerobes? taxa previously associated inflammatory bowel disease? butyrate producers? mucin-utilisers? TaxSEA implements idea R package using curated biological databases define thousands groups, applying rank-based enrichment test. hood, TaxSEA also handles lot practical complexity harmonising taxon names across databases, converting identifiers, providing consistently formatted resources different knowledge bases can used together.

what: But isn’t this what functional profiling tools (e.g. HUMAnN3) do?
title: Why use taxon set enrichment analysis?
text: really. Functional profiling tools work directly gene families pathways. TaxSEA works traits linked taxa (species/strains) based prior knowledge curated resources. approaches related, . example, may know species can utilise mucin vitro work, even precise genes pathways responsible unclear (inconsistently annotated). case, trait-based grouping can capture biology pathway-based methods might miss. Similarly, TaxSEA can tell whether data recapitulates microbial signature previously reported another disease context — something functional tools designed . TaxSEA also lightweight: needs species label plus rank (e.g. log2 fold change correlation) runs seconds laptop. meant replace functional profiling, complement — providing biological context prioritisation invest time resources deeper functional analyses.

title: TaxSEA
text: TaxSEA technique move analysisng individual microbes looking groups microbes shared functional characteristic. Traditional microbiome analysis tools often look individual microbes going . sounds sensible human microbiome studies can fail apart everyone’s microbiome unique, species shared across people. TaxSEA doesn’t test individual species rather asks group species shared characteristic altered groups people. example seeing shift bugs increased oxygen tolerance, increase bugs produce certain metabolite enzyme, even seeing change bugs known disease association humans. want know check paper, find approach far reproducible standard Differential Abundance (DA) analysis well capable extracting biologically meaningful patterns. TaxSEA usually can run within seconds standard hardware. TaxSEA supports three complementary analysis modes: Enrichment using public reference databases ORA – -Representation Analysis Enrichment using taxonomic sets Modes 1 2 use taxon-set databases answer slightly different questions. Mode 1 default reccomend cases takes input list bacteria rank (E.g. fold change). tests whether taxon sets database skewed one end distribution another. Mode 2 uses database takes input list bacterial names. answering similar question approach often less powerful requires hard cut-select bacteria interest. Mode 3 allows users test differences particular taxonomic rank. example instead just summing aggregating species genus. see distribution species within genus different groups. powerful approach simply summing/aggregating rank can risk missing can get shifts within taxon. approach implemented taxon_set_ranks() function. short, TaxSEA aims make easy intepret changes microbiome data. TaxSEA takes input vector species names rank. example log2 fold changes Spearman’s rho. Note: Although TaxSEA principle can applied microbiome data source, databases utilized largely cover human associated microbiomes human gut microbiome particular. database testing TaxSEA likely perform best human gut microbiome data.

title: TaxSEA
text: default TaxSEA utilizes taxon sets generated six reference databases (BacDive,gutMGene, GMrepo v2, MiMeDB, mBodyMap, BugSigDB). See examples using custom databases taxonomically defined taxon sets. Please cite appropriate database using: Schober et al. BacDive 2025: core database prokaryotic strain data. Nucleic Acids Res. 2025. Cheng et al. gutMGene: comprehensive database target genes gut microbes microbial metabolites. Nucleic Acids Res. 2022. Dai et al. GMrepo v2: curated human gut microbiome database special focus disease markers cross-dataset comparison Nucleic Acids Res. 2022. Wishart et. al. MiMeDB: Human Microbial Metabolome Database Nucleic Acids Res. 2023. Jin et al. mBodyMap: curated database microbes across human body associations health diseases. Nucleic Acids Res. 2022. Geistlinger et al. BugSigDB captures patterns differential abundance across broad range host-associated microbial signatures. Nature Biotech. 2023.

title: TaxSEA
text: TaxSEA supports multiple input types, depending analysis mode choose:

title: TaxSEA
text: provide named numeric vector : names taxa (species genus) values ranks signed statistics (e.g. log2 fold changes, correlation coefficients) enrichment mode, input must include taxa tested analysis. apply significance threshold pre-filter taxa running TaxSEA. method relies full distribution values detect coordinated shifts across taxon sets.

title: TaxSEA
text: provide character vector taxa names representing taxa interest (.e. “hit list”). ranking numeric values required TaxSEA tests whether taxa -represented predefined taxon sets mode appropriate presence/absence binary data Input taxa names format like one following Species name. E.g. “Bifidobacterium longum”, “Bifidobacterium_longum” Genus name. E.g. “Bifidobacterium” NCBI ID E.g. 216816
code: #Input IDs with the full taxonomic lineage should be split up. E.g. x <- "d__Bacteria.p__Actinobacteriota.c__Actinomycetes.o__Bifidobacteriales.f__Bifidobacteriaceae.g__Bifidobacterium" x <- strsplit(x,split="\\.")[[1]][6] x <- gsub("g__","",x)  ## Running this through a vector of IDs may look something like the following #new_ids <- sapply(as.character(old_ids),function(y) {strsplit(x = y,split="\\.")[[1]][6]}) #new_ids <- gsub("g__","",new_ids)  ## Example test data library(TaxSEA) data("TaxSEA_test_data") head(sample(TaxSEA_test_data),4)

title: TaxSEA
text: output list three data frames providing enrichment results metabolite producers, health/disease associations, published signatures BugSigDB. dataframe 5 columns taxonSetName - name taxon set tested median_rank - simply median rank across detected members set. allows see direction change P value - Kolmogorov-Smirnov test P value. FDR - P value adjusted multiple testing. TaxonSet - Returns list taxa set show driving signal

title: TaxSEA
text: Many users may want utilise TaxSEA custom database. example testing flag TaxSEA function “custom_db” expects input named list vectors. format default TaxSEA database. Note: using custom_db flag disables automatic ID conversion NCBI API lookup. However functionality available via functions
code: # Perform enrichment analysis using TaxSEA custom_taxsea_results <- TaxSEA(taxon_ranks = log2_fold_changes, custom_db = custom_taxon_sets) custom_taxsea_results <- custom_taxsea_results$custom_sets

what: Testing for differences in taxonomically defined sets
title: TaxSEA
text: addition taxon sets defined public databases , users can define sets based taxonomy data. implemtned taxon_rank_sets() function takes input set taxa ranks (similar enrichment testing ) either table taxonomic lineage TreeSummarizedExperiment object. See examples approaches. Current methods test higher taxonomic levels (e.g., phylum family), involve aggregating counts. However, approach may miss opposing shifts individual species cancel , obscuring meaningful biological patterns. instance, antibiotic treatment may suppress certain species allowing resistant species within genus expand occupy vacant niche, creating ecological shift appears net change broader taxonomic levels. Whereas database testing works best shotgun metagenomic data order sufficient resolution. approach much widely applicable including testing amplicon data 16S rRNA gene sequencing.
code: #### Enrichment testing with taxonomically defined ranks   # --- Example 1: Data frame input --- # Create a lineage data frame (e.g., parsed from curatedMetagenomicData) # The 'species' column must match the names in taxon_ranks.  lineage_df <- data.frame(   species = c("Cutibacterium_acnes", "Klebsiella_pneumoniae",               "Propionibacterium_humerusii", "Moraxella_osloensis",               "Enhydrobacter_aerosaccus", "Staphylococcus_capitis",               "Staphylococcus_epidermidis", "Staphylococcus_aureus",               "Escherichia_coli", "Enterobacter_cloacae",               "Pseudomonas_aeruginosa", "Acinetobacter_baumannii",               "Lactobacillus_rhamnosus", "Lactobacillus_acidophilus",               "Bifidobacterium_longum", "Bifidobacterium_breve"),   kingdom = rep("Bacteria", 16),   phylum = c("Actinobacteria", "Proteobacteria",              "Actinobacteria", "Proteobacteria",              "Proteobacteria", "Firmicutes",              "Firmicutes", "Firmicutes",              "Proteobacteria", "Proteobacteria",              "Proteobacteria", "Proteobacteria",              "Firmicutes", "Firmicutes",              "Actinobacteria", "Actinobacteria"),   class = c("Actinobacteria", "Gammaproteobacteria",             "Actinobacteria", "Gammaproteobacteria",             "Alphaproteobacteria", "Bacilli",             "Bacilli", "Bacilli",             "Gammaproteobacteria", "Gammaproteobacteria",             "Gammaproteobacteria", "Gammaproteobacteria",             "Bacilli", "Bacilli",             "Actinobacteria", "Actinobacteria"),   order = c("Propionibacteriales", "Enterobacterales",             "Propionibacteriales", "Pseudomonadales",             "Rhodospirillales", "Bacillales",             "Bacillales", "Bacillales",             "Enterobacterales", "Enterobacterales",             "Pseudomonadales", "Pseudomonadales",             "Lactobacillales", "Lactobacillales",             "Bifidobacteriales", "Bifidobacteriales"),   family = c("Propionibacteriaceae", "Enterobacteriaceae",              "Propionibacteriaceae", "Moraxellaceae",              "Rhodospirillaceae", "Staphylococcaceae",              "Staphylococcaceae", "Staphylococcaceae",              "Enterobacteriaceae", "Enterobacteriaceae",              "Pseudomonadaceae", "Moraxellaceae",              "Lactobacillaceae", "Lactobacillaceae",              "Bifidobacteriaceae", "Bifidobacteriaceae"),   genus = c("Cutibacterium", "Klebsiella",             "Cutibacterium", "Moraxella",             "Enhydrobacter", "Staphylococcus",             "Staphylococcus", "Staphylococcus",             "Escherichia", "Enterobacter",             "Pseudomonas", "Acinetobacter",             "Lactobacillus", "Lactobacillus",             "Bifidobacterium", "Bifidobacterium"),   stringsAsFactors = FALSE )  set.seed(42) fc <- setNames(rnorm(16), lineage_df$species) results <- taxon_rank_sets(fc, lineage_df, min_set_size = 2) names(results) results$family   # --- Example 2: SummarizedExperiment / TreeSummarizedExperiment input --- library(mia) library(TaxSEA) library(ALDEx2)  data(GlobalPatterns, package = "mia") tse <- GlobalPatterns  # Subset to two sample types for a two-group comparison tse <- tse[, colData(tse)$SampleType %in% c("Feces", "Soil")]  # Filter low-prevalence features (present in at least 2 samples) tse <- tse[rowSums(assay(tse, "counts") > 0) >= 2, ]  # Run ALDEx2 set.seed(1) x <- aldex.clr(   reads = assay(tse, "counts"),   conds = as.character(colData(tse)$SampleType),   mc.samples = 128,   denom = "all",   verbose = FALSE ) x_tt <- aldex.ttest(x, paired.test = FALSE, verbose = FALSE) x_effect <- aldex.effect(x, CI = TRUE, verbose = FALSE) aldex_out <- data.frame(x_tt, x_effect)  # Use ALDEx2 effect size as ranking metric fc <- aldex_out$effect names(fc) <- rownames(aldex_out)  # Run taxon rank set enrichment directly from the TSE results <- taxon_rank_sets(fc, tse, min_set_size = 5)  names(results)    # Kingdom, Phylum, Class, Order, Family, Genus head(results$Family) head(results$Genus)

title: TaxSEA

code: library(fgsea) #This package is installable via Bioconductor data(TaxSEA_DB) #Convert input names to NCBI taxon ids names(TaxSEA_test_data) = get_ncbi_taxon_ids(names(TaxSEA_test_data)) TaxSEA_test_data = TaxSEA_test_data[!is.na(names(TaxSEA_test_data))]  #Run fgsea fgsea_results <- fgsea(TaxSEA_db, TaxSEA_test_data, minSize=5, maxSize=500)

text: taxon_ranks Named numeric vector statistics (e.g., log2 fold changes).   Required enrichment. input_taxa Character vector taxa treat "hits"/selected taxa.   Required ORA. mode Character. Default 5. max_set_size Maximum size taxon sets include analysis.  Default 100. custom_db user-provided list taxon sets. NULL (default),   built-database used.

what: Single-Sample Taxon Set Enrichment Analysis — ssTaxSEA
title: Single-Sample Taxon Set Enrichment Analysis — ssTaxSEA
text: Computes per-sample enrichment scores taxon sets using ssGSEA-style approach. Counts CLR-transformed, taxon z-scored across samples capture -sample variation. Per-sample enrichment computed ranking sample's z-scores applying weighted running-sum statistic taxon sets TaxSEA database.

title: Single-Sample Taxon Set Enrichment Analysis — ssTaxSEA
code: ssTaxSEA(   counts,   lookup_missing = FALSE,   min_set_size = 5,   max_set_size = 300,   custom_db = NULL )

title: Single-Sample Taxon Set Enrichment Analysis — ssTaxSEA
text: counts numeric matrix, data.frame, SummarizedExperiment/TreeSummarizedExperiment object. matrix/data.frame input: rows taxa, columns samples, row names must taxon names (e.g. species names NCBI IDs). SummarizedExperiment input: first assay used rownames() provide taxon identifiers. lookup_missing Logical indicating whether fetch missing NCBI IDs via NCBI API. Default FALSE. min_set_size Minimum size taxon sets include. Default 5. max_set_size Maximum size taxon sets include. Default 300. custom_db user-provided list taxon sets. NULL (default), built-TaxSEA database used (excluding BugSigDB).

title: Single-Sample Taxon Set Enrichment Analysis — ssTaxSEA
text: list two elements: scores matrix (samples x taxon sets) enrichment       scores. Positive scores indicate set taxa tend       higher abundance sample relative cohort. pvalues matrix (samples x taxon sets) KS test       p-values sample-set combination.

title: Single-Sample Taxon Set Enrichment Analysis — ssTaxSEA
text: approach works follows: Raw counts CLR-transformed (centered log-ratio     pseudocount 0.5 zeros). taxon z-scored across samples,     values represent much higher lower taxon     given sample relative cohort mean. sample, z-scores ranked     ssGSEA-style weighted running-sum enrichment score     computed taxon set. KS test p-value also computed per sample per set. cohort-relative approach ensures taxon sets consistently elevated subset samples (e.g. disease samples) produce high enrichment scores samples, even taxa abundant within single sample.

title: Single-Sample Taxon Set Enrichment Analysis — ssTaxSEA
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # From a count matrix (taxa x samples) counts <- matrix(rpois(500, lambda = 10), nrow = 50, ncol = 10) rownames(counts) <- paste0("Taxon_", seq_len(50)) colnames(counts) <- paste0("Sample_", seq_len(10)) res <- ssTaxSEA(counts, custom_db = list(   set1 = paste0("Taxon_", 1:10),   set2 = paste0("Taxon_", 20:30) ), min_set_size = 2) head(res$scores) head(res$pvalues) } # }

what: Taxon Rank Set Enrichment Analysis — taxon_rank_sets
title: Taxon Rank Set Enrichment Analysis — taxon_rank_sets
text: Groups species taxonomic ranks performs TaxSEA enrichment analysis rank level. Returns named list data frames, one per taxonomic rank (excluding species).

title: Taxon Rank Set Enrichment Analysis — taxon_rank_sets
code: taxon_rank_sets(taxon_ranks, lineage_df, min_set_size = 5, max_set_size = 100)

title: Taxon Rank Set Enrichment Analysis — taxon_rank_sets
text: taxon_ranks named numeric vector log2 fold changes. Names feature identifiers matching species column lineage_df, matching rownames() SummarizedExperiment/TreeSummarizedExperiment. lineage_df Either data frame   SummarizedExperiment/TreeSummarizedExperiment object. Data frame input: Must include species column   one taxonomic rank columns (e.g., kingdom, phylum,   class, order, family, genus). species column used   matching excluded enrichment analysis. SummarizedExperiment input: Taxonomy extracted   rowData() feature identifiers rownames().   mia package installed, taxonomyRanks()   used identify taxonomic rank columns; otherwise   rowData() columns used. Species rank column   automatically excluded analysis. Requires   SummarizedExperiment package. min_set_size Minimum number species set include analysis. Default 5. max_set_size Maximum number species set include analysis. Default 100.

title: Taxon Rank Set Enrichment Analysis — taxon_rank_sets
text: named list data frames, one per taxonomic rank.   data frame contains columns: taxonSetName,   median_rank_of_set_members, PValue, Test_statistic, FDR.   Ranks produce valid sets (e.g., due size filtering)   included empty data frames message.

title: Taxon Rank Set Enrichment Analysis — taxon_rank_sets
